abstract.p: Excerpts from previously published reviews of restaurants in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood suitable for Mother's Day brunch (Good Eating column) (M)

block.p: BRIGHT FOOD SHOP + (212) 243-4433; 218 Eighth Avenue, between 21st and 22nd Street; $$; no smoking; cash only.

This spare, minimalist former luncheonette made its reputation by serving an exciting blend of Asian and Southwestern ingredients, but has been emphasizing its Southwestern roots lately. Breakfast and lunch choices include cornmeal pecan griddlecakes with fruit and maple syrup; huevos rancheros on corn tortillas with black beans and sour cream; smoked whitefish maki with wasabi cream cheese, green chili scrambled eggs and cucumber salad; Tijuana caesar salad with smoky cornbread croutons; Yucatan salmon wrap with mango slaw and habanero achiote sauce; and eggs, any style, with peppered slab of bacon or chorizo patty, roasted potatoes and smoky cornbread. ($25 and Under: 8/15/97)

CUBA LIBRE + (212) 206-0038; 200 Eighth Avenue, at 20th Street; $$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

Some dishes are so good that you simply want to eat and sigh at this pan-Latin restaurant in Chelsea. Brunch entrees include brioche French toast with guava jam and house made syrup; eggs any style with grilled hanger steak and pico de gallo; wild mushroom tamal with hominy stew; Spanish goat cheese and roasted vegetable omelet; and traditional Cuban sandwich with viguron salad and malanga chips. Cocktails include mango, guava or peach mimosas, Bloody Marys and caipirinhas. Breakfast bread is served with honey-pecan butter. ($25 and Under: 2/2/00)
GARDEN OF EDEN ++ (212) 675-6300; 162 West 23rd Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue; $; all major credit cards.

Along with the gorgeous produce and the usual collection of vinegars, oils and condiments, this takeout market offers a paradise of prepared foods. There are 20 sandwiches, including fresh roast turkey, brie, lettuce, tomato and honey mustard; prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, roasted pepper, olive oil and vinegar; nova, cream cheese, onion and tomato on a bagel; and roasted vegetables with pesto sauce. Soups include creamy cucumber; gazpacho; Manhattan clam chowder; and mushroom and barley. Hot pasta dishes include pasta with eggplant; zucchini, asparagus, broccoli or cauliflower; pasta with salmon; and pasta al pesto. Other entrees include lemon chicken; stuffed or grilled cornish hens; beef stew; loin of veal with mushrooms; and chile con carne. (Article: 9/8/99)
GASCOGNE +++ (212) 675-6564; 158 Eighth Avenue, between 17th and 18th Streets; $$$; smoking in the garden and at the bar; all major credit cards.

Whether you eat brunch in the pretty Chelsea Garden or have hearty French country cooking in the cozy dining room, be sure to try the Armagnac. Appetizers for brunch include baked mussels in garlic butter; stuffed crepes with duck confit and goat cheese; and lobster bisque. Main courses include classical Southwestern omelet with leeks, bacon and potatoes; eggs sunny side up with sauteed foie gras; an assortment of Gascony sausages and smoked duck; and pan-seared salmon fillet, cepes and artichoke. Creme caramel is served with coffee or tea. (New York Today: April 1998)
LE GAMIN +++ (212) 243-8864; 183 Ninth Avenue, at 21st Street; $$; no smoking; cash only.

Le Gamin offers a typical cafe menu of salads, sandwiches and omelets, but the best dishes are the crepes. With a frothy bowl of cafe au lait, a ham and melted cheese crepe followed by a lemon crepe makes a wonderful light meal. Options for starters include a mixed fresh fruit salad; muesli with milk or yogurt and fresh fruits; and chocolate croissants. Assorted crepes include spicy sausage; goat cheese and leek; turkey breast, ratatouille and goat cheese; smoked salmon, grilled vegetables and fresh basil cream; and butter and sugar with ice cream. Salads include warm goat cheese with croutons, tomato, walnuts and raisins; tuna with hard-cooked egg, roasted pepper, potato, tomato, string beans, black olives and anchovies; and cold roast chicken, grilled vegetables, potato, ratatouille, tomato and mesclun. (New York Today: April 1998)
MARKT ++ (212) 727-3314; 401 West 14th Street, at Ninth Avenue; $$; no smoking; all major credit cards.

Markt's look is all-brasserie, with dark wood, etched glass and vintage beer posters. Belgian beers, 29 of them, are the focus of Markt. Entrees include whole wheat bread with fresh ricotta cheese, radish and cucumber; Flemish toast, served with fresh fruit and maple syrup; poached eggs with sauteed spinach and mousseline sauce; omelet with Norwegian smoked salmon, cream cheese and fresh dill; homemade waffles with fresh strawberries and whipped cream; chocolate-chip pancakes with Belgian chocolate sauce; blueberry pancakes with maple syrup; and Belgian-style crepes, served with a choice of sugar, confiture or brown sugar. Other items on the menu include salads, soups and seafood, including oysters, chilled shrimp and lobster. (Article: 1/6/99)
